config.objective: Identify fMRI studies of working memory in schizophrenia

search.query: schizophrenia AND working memory AND fMRI

exclusion_criteria: Review articles, meta-analyses, or theoretical papers
Non-fMRI imaging modalities (e.g., PET, EEG, MEG)
Studies without a control or comparison group

studies.title: Working memory in schizophrenia: The role of the locus coeruleus and its relation to functional brain networks.
studies.abstract: Evidence suggests functional brain networks, especially the executive control network (ECN) and default mode network (DMN), to be abnormal in schizophrenia. Dysfunctions within the locus coeruleus (LC)-noradrenaline (NE) system, which is supposed to be pivotal to modulate neuronal network activation during executive control (e.g., working memory function), are also considered to play a vital role in the occurrence of positive (e.g., hallucinatory) or negative (e.g., inattentive) symptoms in these patients. In the present study, we sought to shed further light on the role of the LC-NE system in patients with schizophrenia. More specifically, we wanted to improve our understanding of the relationship and possible disturbances of the ECN and DMN during a working memory task in patients. A total of 58 healthy control subjects and 40 medicated patients with schizophrenia were investigated using a working memory 3-back task during functional magnetic resonance imaging. Main findings of our present study were differential dynamics of ECN and DMN blood oxygenation level-dependent (BOLD) activations with increasing task demands in both patients and controls. Moreover, we found increased BOLD activation in the LC in patients compared to controls in the interaction contrast between groups and conditions. LC BOLD activation significantly correlated with both, the main hub of the ECN, that is, the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex, and of the DMN, that is, the posterior cingulate cortex. Thus, the LC-NE system seems to be crucial in modulating neuronal network activity in a 3-back working memory task and might significantly contribute to cognitive impairments in schizophrenia.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Human study with 40 medicated schizophrenia patients and 58 healthy controls; used task-based fMRI (3-back working memory task); case-control design with between-group comparisons. Meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI working memory studies in schizophrenia.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is a human case-control fMRI study of working memory in schizophrenia. Sample: 40 schizophrenia patients and 58 healthy controls. Neuroimaging: task-based fMRI acquired at 3T with EPI sequences and brainstem-focused analyses. Design: between-group (patients vs. controls) comparisons and subgroup analyses. Task: parametric n-back working memory paradigm (x/1/2/3-back). No exclusion criteria are met (not an animal study, not a review/meta-analysis, uses fMRI, includes a control group). Therefore all inclusion criteria are satisfied.

studies.title: Combining fMRI and DISC1 gene haplotypes to understand working memory-related brain activity in schizophrenia.
studies.abstract: The DISC1 gene is one of the most relevant susceptibility genes for psychosis. However, the complex genetic landscape of this locus, which includes protective and risk variants in interaction, may have hindered consistent conclusions on how DISC1 contributes to schizophrenia (SZ) liability. Analysis from haplotype approaches and brain-based phenotypes can contribute to understanding DISC1 role in the neurobiology of this disorder. We assessed the brain correlates of DISC1 haplotypes associated with SZ through a functional neuroimaging genetics approach. First, we tested the association of two DISC1 haplotypes, the HEP1 (rs6675281-1000731-rs999710) and the HEP3 (rs151229-rs3738401), with the risk for SZ in a sample of 138 healthy subjects (HS) and 238 patients. This approach allowed the identification of three haplotypes associated with SZ (HEP1-CTG, HEP3-GA and HEP3-AA). Second, we explored whether these haplotypes exerted differential effects on n-back associated brain activity in a subsample of 70 HS compared to 70 patients (diagnosis × haplotype interaction effect). These analyses evidenced that HEP3-GA and HEP3-AA modulated working memory functional response conditional to the health/disease status in the cuneus, precuneus, middle cingulate cortex and the ventrolateral and dorsolateral prefrontal cortices. Our results are the first to show a diagnosis-based effect of DISC1 haplotypes on working memory-related brain activity, emphasising its role in SZ.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Human study using task-based fMRI (n-back working memory) with schizophrenia patients and healthy controls in a case-control design; meets all inclusion criteria and no exclusion criteria are present in the abstract.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: The study meets all inclusion criteria: human participants (patients with schizophrenia and healthy controls), task-based fMRI neuroimaging (n-back working memory paradigm), and a case–control design (neuroimaging subsample of 70 patients and 70 matched controls; genetic association sample also includes controls). The methods explicitly describe fMRI acquisition, n-back task contrasts (2-back vs baseline, 2-back vs 1-back) and whole-brain analyses of working memory-related activations. No exclusion criteria apply (not an animal study, not a review/meta-analysis, uses fMRI, includes control/comparison group). Therefore it is appropriate to include this study in a meta-analysis of fMRI working memory in schizophrenia.

studies.title: Brain state dynamics and working memory in patients with schizophrenia and unaffected siblings.
studies.abstract: Working memory (WM) deficits are a key feature of schizophrenia and are also seen in unaffected siblings. These deficits might arise  from disrupted transitions from one brain state to another. Using a robust algorithm called the Bayesian Switching Dynamical System (BSDS), we studied hidden brain states and their transitions during a WM task in people with schizophrenia.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Human study examining working memory in people with schizophrenia and unaffected siblings using a brain-state analysis during a WM task. Abstract does not explicitly state fMRI, but it investigates task-based brain-state dynamics that likely involve neuroimaging and includes patient and control-like comparison groups; full text needed to confirm fMRI modality and detailed case-control design.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This study reports original human fMRI research using a task-based working memory paradigm (n-back) in patients with schizophrenia, unaffected siblings, and healthy controls. It uses a case-control design with clearly described participant groups (SZs, SBs, HCs), MRI acquisition and preprocessing, ROI-based analyses, and task-related outcomes. All inclusion criteria are met: human participants, fMRI neuroimaging, task-based working memory paradigm, and comparison groups. No exclusion criteria apply (not an animal study, review, or non-fMRI modality). Therefore it should be included in the review of fMRI studies of working memory in schizophrenia.

studies.title: Brain network dynamics during working memory are modulated by dopamine and diminished in schizophrenia.
studies.abstract: Dynamical brain state transitions are critical for flexible working memory but the network mechanisms are incompletely understood. Here, we show that working memory performance entails brain-wide switching between activity states using a combination of functional magnetic resonance imaging in healthy controls and individuals with schizophrenia, pharmacological fMRI, genetic analyses and network control theory. The stability of states relates to dopamine D1 receptor gene expression while state transitions are influenced by D2 receptor expression and pharmacological modulation. Individuals with schizophrenia show altered network control properties, including a more diverse energy landscape and decreased stability of working memory representations. Our results demonstrate the relevance of dopamine signaling for the steering of whole-brain network dynamics during working memory and link these processes to schizophrenia pathophysiology.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Human participants (healthy controls and individuals with schizophrenia), uses task-based fMRI (pharmacological fMRI), and a case-control/experimental design focused on working memory. Meets all inclusion criteria; no exclusion criteria evident from the abstract.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is a human study (N=202 total: 178 healthy controls, 24 individuals with schizophrenia), uses task-based fMRI (BOLD EPI) during an N-back working memory paradigm, and employs a case-control design comparing schizophrenia patients to matched healthy controls. The methods, participants, and outcomes explicitly report working-memory-related brain activity and between-group comparisons. No exclusion criteria are violated (not an animal study, review, or non-fMRI modality only). Therefore it is eligible for inclusion in the review of fMRI studies of working memory in schizophrenia.

studies.title: The neural and molecular basis of working memory function in psychosis: a multimodal PET-fMRI study.
studies.abstract: Working memory (WM) deficits predict clinical and functional outcomes in schizophrenia but are poorly understood and unaddressed by existing treatments. WM encoding and WM retrieval have not been investigated in schizophrenia without the confounds of illness chronicity or the use of antipsychotics and illicit substances. Moreover, it is unclear if WM deficits may be linked to cannabinoid 1 receptor dysfunction in schizophrenia. Sixty-six volunteers (35 controls, 31 drug-free patients with diagnoses of schizophrenia or schizoaffective disorder) completed the Sternberg Item-Recognition paradigm during an fMRI scan. Neural activation during WM encoding and WM retrieval was indexed using the blood-oxygen-level-dependent hemodynamic response. A subset of volunteers (20 controls, 20 drug-free patients) underwent a dynamic PET scan to measure [
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Human case-control study with drug-free schizophrenia/schizoaffective patients and healthy controls. Uses task-based working memory fMRI (Sternberg paradigm) with neural activation measured via BOLD; meets all inclusion criteria. PET was an additional modality for a subset but fMRI data are primary.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This study meets all inclusion criteria: human participants (first-episode psychosis patients and healthy controls), task-based fMRI (Sternberg Item-Recognition Paradigm) was used to probe working memory (encoding and retrieval), and the design is case-control (patients vs. matched healthy volunteers). Although PET was also used to assess CB1 receptor availability, that does not violate exclusion criteria since fMRI neuroimaging and task-based WM outcomes are primary and clearly reported. The study reports task performance and whole-brain and ROI fMRI results comparing groups, satisfying the review objective of identifying fMRI studies of working memory in schizophrenia.

studies.title: Mechanisms of Working Memory Impairment in Schizophrenia.
studies.abstract: The neural correlates of working memory (WM) impairment in schizophrenia remain a key puzzle in understanding the cognitive deficits and dysfunction of dorsolateral prefrontal cortex observed in this disorder. We sought to determine whether patients with schizophrenia exhibit an alteration in the inverted-U relationship between WM load and activation that we recently observed in healthy individuals and whether this could account for WM deficits in this population.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Human study of schizophrenia assessing working memory load–related brain activation (dorsolateral PFC) using task-based imaging and comparing patients to controls, indicating fMRI case-control design. Meets all inclusion criteria based on the abstract.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is a human fMRI study using a task-based working memory paradigm (Self-Ordered Working Memory Task). It employs a case-control design with 51 patients (21 unmedicated, 30 medicated) and 45 healthy controls, and reports task performance and task-based BOLD fMRI results (ROI and whole-brain analyses). It is not an animal study, review, or non-fMRI modality, and includes a control/comparison group. All inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

studies.title: Enhancement of the left frontoparietal network through real-time functional magnetic resonance imaging functional connectivity-informed neurofeedback and its impact on working memory in schizophrenia: A pilot study.
studies.abstract: Cognitive impairment in schizophrenia shows limited improvement with pharmacotherapy, indicating a need for effective treatment. The frontoparietal network supports working memory, and a biomarker has successfully predicted performance in patients, with the left frontoparietal network contributing the most to working memory. We hypothesized that enhancing functional connectivity in this network through real-time neurofeedback (NF) will improve working memory in patients with schizophrenia.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Human fMRI neurofeedback pilot study targeting working memory in schizophrenia; meets fMRI and working memory criteria. Abstract does not specify a control/comparison group, so include for full-text review to confirm design.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is a human fMRI study in patients with schizophrenia using a task-based working memory paradigm (N-back; digit span) and real-time fMRI functional connectivity–informed neurofeedback. It employed a two-arm nonrandomized controlled experimental design with a control group, meeting the requirement for a comparison group. fMRI acquisition and task-based analyses (N‑back localizer and NF runs) are central to the methods and outcomes, and cognitive working-memory outcomes are reported. No exclusion criteria (animal study, review, non-fMRI modality, or lack of comparator) apply. Note: the control group did not undergo MRI, but a behavioral control/comparison group was present, and the study still qualifies for inclusion under the review’s criteria focusing on fMRI working-memory studies in schizophrenia.

studies.title: An experimental medicine study of the phosphodiesterase-4 inhibitor, roflumilast, on working memory-related brain activity and episodic memory in schizophrenia patients.
studies.abstract: Schizophrenia is associated with impairments in cognitive functioning yet there are no approved drugs to treat these deficits.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Title reports working memory-related brain activity in schizophrenia and describes an experimental medicine study; however the abstract does not explicitly state fMRI or presence of a control/comparison group. Insufficient detail to confirm fMRI and design from abstract alone — include for full-text review.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is a human experimental study in patients with schizophrenia using task-based fMRI (DOT delayed-response spatial working memory task). Design is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled three-period crossover (within-subject experimental comparison), providing a control/placebo condition. The study reports fMRI outcomes related to working memory (DLPFC activity) and behavioral working memory measures. It is not an animal study, review, or non-fMRI modality, and includes appropriate comparisons, so it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

studies.title: Origins of spatial working memory deficits in schizophrenia: an event-related FMRI and near-infrared spectroscopy study.
studies.abstract: Abnormal prefrontal functioning plays a central role in the working memory (WM) deficits of schizophrenic patients, but the nature of the relationship between WM and prefrontal activation remains undetermined. Using two functional neuroimaging methods, we investigated the neural correlates of remembering and forgetting in schizophrenic and healthy participants. We focused on the brain activation during WM maintenance phase with event-related functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI). We also examined oxygenated hemoglobin changes in relation to memory performance with the near-infrared spectroscopy (NIRS) using the same spatial WM task. Distinct types of correct and error trials were segregated for analysis. fMRI data indicated that prefrontal activation was increased during WM maintenance on correct trials in both schizophrenic and healthy subjects. However, a significant difference was observed in the functional asymmetry of frontal activation pattern. Healthy subjects showed increased activation in the right frontal, temporal and cingulate regions. Schizophrenic patients showed greater activation compared with control subjects in left frontal, temporal and parietal regions as well as in right frontal regions. We also observed increased 'false memory' errors in schizophrenic patients, associated with increased prefrontal activation and resembling the activation pattern observed on the correct trials. NIRS data replicated the fMRI results. Thus, increased frontal activity was correlated with the accuracy of WM in both healthy control and schizophrenic participants. The major difference between the two groups concerned functional asymmetry; healthy subjects recruited right frontal regions during spatial WM maintenance whereas schizophrenic subjects recruited a wider network in both hemispheres to achieve the same level of memory performance. Increased "false memory" errors and accompanying bilateral prefrontal activation in schizophrenia suggest that the etiology of memory errors must be considered when comparing group performances. Finally, the concordance of fMRI and NIRS data supports NIRS as an alternative functional neuroimaging method for psychiatric research.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Human case-control study comparing schizophrenic patients and healthy controls using event-related fMRI during a spatial working memory task; task-based WM paradigm and fMRI modality clearly reported, meeting all inclusion criteria.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is a human, task-based fMRI study of working memory in schizophrenia with a case-control design. Experiment 1 reports event-related fMRI data from schizophrenic outpatients and healthy controls performing a spatial delayed-response working memory task, directly addressing the review objective. It is not an animal study, review, or theoretical paper, and includes a control/comparison group. Although the paper also includes NIRS (Experiment 2), the presence of fMRI data meeting all inclusion criteria qualifies it for inclusion. Note: sample size in the fMRI experiment is small (8 patients, 7 controls), but this does not violate inclusion criteria.

studies.title: Effect of mGluR2 positive allosteric modulation on frontostriatal working memory activation in schizophrenia.
studies.abstract: Negative symptoms and cognitive deficits contribute strongly to disability in schizophrenia, and are resistant to existing medications. Recent drug development has targeted enhanced NMDA function by increasing mGluR2/3 signaling. However, the clinical utility of such agents remains uncertain, and markers of brain circuit function are critical for clarifying mechanisms and understanding individual differences in efficacy. We conducted a double-blind, placebo-controlled, randomized cross-over (14 day washout) pilot study evaluating adjunctive use of the mGluR2 positive allosteric modulator AZD8529 (80 mg daily for 3 days), in chronic stable patients with schizophrenia (n = 26 analyzed). We focused on 3 T fMRI response in frontostriatal regions during an n-back working memory task, testing the hypothesis that AZD8529 produces fMRI changes that correlate with improvement in negative symptoms and cognition. We found that AZD8529 did not produce significant group-average effects on symptoms or cognitive accuracy. However, AZD8529 did increase n-back fMRI activation in striatum (p < 0.0001) and anterior cingulate/paracingulate (p = 0.002). Greater drug-versus-placebo effects on caudate activation significantly correlated with greater reductions in PANSS negative symptom scores (r = -0.42, p = 0.031), and exploratory correlations suggested broader effects across multiple symptom domains and regions of interest. These findings demonstrate that fMRI responses to mGluR2 positive modulation relate to individual differences in symptom reduction, and could be pursued for future biomarker development. Negative clinical results at the group level should not lead to premature termination of investigation of this mechanism, which may benefit an important subset of individuals with schizophrenia. Imaging biomarkers may reveal therapeutic mechanisms, and help guide treatment toward specific populations.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Human participants with schizophrenia; 3T fMRI used; randomized double-blind placebo-controlled cross-over (experimental) design; task-based n-back working memory paradigm reported. No exclusion criteria met and abstract provides sufficient information to determine eligibility.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is a human fMRI study in individuals with schizophrenia using a task-based working memory paradigm (fractal n-back). The design is an experimental, double-blind, placebo-controlled, randomized within-subject crossover comparing drug versus placebo, providing a valid comparison group. BOLD fMRI was acquired and analyzed with task-based contrasts focusing on working-memory-related ROIs (DLPFC, ACC, striatum), and primary outcomes include task fMRI activation. No exclusion criteria are violated (not an animal study, review, or non-fMRI modality). Although there is no healthy control group, the study meets the review’s inclusion criteria of human participants, fMRI neuroimaging, experimental design, and task-based working memory paradigm, so it should be included.

studies.title: An event-related FMRI study of phonological verbal working memory in schizophrenia.
studies.abstract: While much is known about the role of prefrontal cortex (PFC) in working memory (WM) deficits of schizophrenia, the nature of the relationship between cognitive components of WM and brain activation patterns remains unclear. We aimed to elucidate the neural correlates of the maintenance component of verbal WM by examining correct and error trials with event-related fMRI.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Human participants; event-related fMRI; task-based verbal working memory paradigm in schizophrenia. Abstract does not explicitly state a control/comparison group, but study clearly meets review objective and other inclusion criteria. Include for full-text review to confirm presence of case-control design and extract data.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is an event-related BOLD fMRI study in human participants directly addressing working memory in schizophrenia. It uses a task-based phonological delayed-match-to-sample working memory paradigm, includes a case-control design (12 patients with schizophrenia/schizoaffective disorder vs 13 healthy controls), and reports task-related fMRI activation comparisons. Imaging modality, participant characteristics, and task clearly meet all inclusion criteria, and no exclusion criteria (animal study, review, non-fMRI modality, or lack of control group) apply.

studies.title: Cerebral Inefficient Activation in Schizophrenia Patients and Their Unaffected Parents during the N-Back Working Memory Task: A Family fMRI Study.
studies.abstract: It has been suggested that working memory deficits is a core feature of symptomatology of schizophrenia, which can be detected in patients and their unaffected relatives. The impairment of working memory has been found related to the abnormal activity of human brain regions in many functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) studies. This study investigated how brain region activation was altered in schizophrenia and how it was inherited independently from performance deficits.
studies.abstract_screening_reason: Human fMRI study using an N-back working memory task comparing schizophrenia patients and their unaffected relatives (family case-control design). Meets all inclusion criteria: human participants, fMRI neuroimaging, task-based working memory paradigm, and comparative design.
studies.fulltext_screening_reason: This is a human fMRI study using a task-based working memory paradigm (N-back). It employs a case-control design with schizophrenia patients and matched healthy controls (also includes unaffected parents vs age-matched controls). Imaging modality is fMRI; outcomes are task-elicited BOLD activations during working memory. All inclusion criteria (human participants, fMRI neuroimaging, case-control/experimental design, task-based working memory) are satisfied, and none of the exclusion criteria (animal study, review/meta-analysis, non-fMRI modality, lack of control group) apply. Therefore the study should be included in the meta-analysis of working memory fMRI in schizophrenia.

abstract_screening_results.reason: This article is a systematic review and meta-analysis of fMRI studies rather than a primary task-based fMRI study with human participants. Inclusion requires original case-control/experimental primary data; review/meta-analysis articles are excluded.
This article is a meta-analysis/systematic review of published fMRI studies rather than an original primary fMRI case-control study. Exclusion criterion: review articles/meta-analyses.

This is a review/theoretical synthesis on episodic memory and cognition in schizophrenia rather than a primary task-based fMRI working memory case-control study. The abstract describes conceptual/therapeutic discussion, so it meets the exclusion criterion for review articles.

Human study with 40 medicated schizophrenia patients and 58 healthy controls; used task-based fMRI (3-back working memory task); case-control design with between-group comparisons. Meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI working memory studies in schizophrenia.

Human study using task-based fMRI (n-back working memory) with schizophrenia patients and healthy controls in a case-control design; meets all inclusion criteria and no exclusion criteria are present in the abstract.

Human study examining working memory in people with schizophrenia and unaffected siblings using a brain-state analysis during a WM task. Abstract does not explicitly state fMRI, but it investigates task-based brain-state dynamics that likely involve neuroimaging and includes patient and control-like comparison groups; full text needed to confirm fMRI modality and detailed case-control design.

Abstract reports investigation of working memory deficits in schizophrenia during task engagement, implying task-based neuroimaging in human patients and likely case-control comparisons. No exclusion criteria (animal, non-fMRI, review, or lack of controls) are clearly met. Methods are not fully detailed in the abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm fMRI modality and control group.

Human case-control study (16 schizophrenia, 21 healthy controls) using task-based verbal working memory fMRI and comparing connectivity between groups. Meets inclusion criteria (human, fMRI, case-control, working memory task).

Human participants (healthy controls and individuals with schizophrenia), uses task-based fMRI (pharmacological fMRI), and a case-control/experimental design focused on working memory. Meets all inclusion criteria; no exclusion criteria evident from the abstract.

Study used EEG and magnetic resonance spectroscopy (MRS) to measure gamma oscillations and GABA levels, not fMRI. Although human case-control working memory task was used, the imaging modality fails the inclusion criterion requiring fMRI.

Confidence 0.70 below threshold 0.75. Abstract mentions working memory in schizophrenia and histamine-3 receptor but does not specify human fMRI methods, participant groups, or a task-based working memory paradigm. Given insufficient methodological detail in the abstract, include for full-text review to determine whether it meets inclusion criteria.

Confidence 0.70 below threshold 0.75. Abstract describes an fMRI study investigating working memory deficits in schizophrenia (replication fMRI study). It meets fMRI and WM focus and targets schizophrenia. The abstract does not explicitly state presence of a control group or task details; insufficient info on case-control status—include for full-text review to confirm design and task.

The study used task-based fMRI in human participants, employed a working memory (spatial delayed match-to-sample) paradigm, and included case-control comparisons (schizophrenia, psychotic bipolar disorder, and healthy controls). All inclusion criteria are clearly met from the abstract.

Human participants (people with schizophrenia and healthy controls); includes fMRI results (posterior parietal BOLD activity) combined with EEG; task-based visual working memory paradigm (visual change detection); case-control design. No exclusion criteria met based on abstract.

The study reports fMRI during an N‑back WM task in patients with schizophrenia but includes only patient participants (no healthy control group) and is an observational within-patient comparison (high vs low anticholinergic burden). It does not meet the inclusion requirement of a case-control or experimental design.

Confidence 0.70 below threshold 0.75. Human case-control study examining visual working memory encoding and neuronal correlates in schizophrenia and first-degree relatives. Abstract indicates neurofunctional investigation of WM consolidation/encoding but does not explicitly state fMRI; insufficient modality detail in abstract, so include for full-text review.

Human participants (first-episode, drug‑naïve schizophrenia and healthy controls); task-based fMRI working memory paradigm with load manipulation; case-control design with direct patient-control comparison. No exclusion criteria met based on abstract.

Human case-control study with drug-free schizophrenia/schizoaffective patients and healthy controls. Uses task-based working memory fMRI (Sternberg paradigm) with neural activation measured via BOLD; meets all inclusion criteria. PET was an additional modality for a subset but fMRI data are primary.
The study uses proton magnetic resonance spectroscopy (MRS) to measure glutamate, not fMRI. This meets the exclusion criterion for non-fMRI imaging modalities.

Population is schizotypal personality disorder (SPD), not schizophrenia; the review targets working-memory fMRI studies in schizophrenia. Abstract also does not clearly state a case-control comparison. Therefore not clearly eligible.

Abstract and title indicate a task-based working memory investigation using functional imaging in schizophrenia (DLPFC inefficiency). While the abstract does not explicitly state a control group, it clearly targets fMRI working-memory effects in patients; include for full-text review to confirm design and controls.

Human fMRI study of working memory in schizophrenia that addresses the review objective. Abstract does not explicitly state a control/comparison group; insufficient information to exclude, so include for full-text review to confirm case-control design.

Title explicitly addresses working memory networks and activation patterns in schizophrenia with comparison to healthy controls, implying a task-based, case-control neuroimaging study. Abstract text is minimal and does not explicitly state fMRI modality or task details; include for full-text review to confirm imaging modality and working memory paradigm.

The study measured serum tryptophan metabolites and used structural MRI (cortical thickness); it does not report task-based fMRI neuroimaging of working memory. Therefore it fails the fMRI neuroimaging inclusion criterion.

This is a review article about assay selection for attention and working memory across disorders, not an original fMRI case-control study. Abstract provides no task-based fMRI data or case-control experimental results; meets exclusion criterion for review articles.

Meets inclusion criteria: human participants, fMRI neuroimaging, case-control design (12 patients, 11 controls), task-based two-back verbal working memory paradigm. No exclusion criteria apparent and abstract provides sufficient methodological detail.
The study uses magnetoencephalography (MEG), not fMRI. The meta-analysis excludes non-fMRI imaging modalities.

Human study of schizophrenia assessing working memory load–related brain activation (dorsolateral PFC) using task-based imaging and comparing patients to controls, indicating fMRI case-control design. Meets all inclusion criteria based on the abstract.

This paper is an activation likelihood estimation (ALE) meta-analysis of working memory training studies, not a primary fMRI study. It meets the exclusion criterion for review/meta-analysis articles and does not report original participant-level fMRI case-control/experimental data.

Abstract addresses working memory in unaffected siblings and refers to neuroimaging/functional (DMN) abnormalities. However, it does not explicitly state fMRI, task paradigm, or control group; insufficient methodological detail—include for full-text screening.

Human fMRI neurofeedback pilot study targeting working memory in schizophrenia; meets fMRI and working memory criteria. Abstract does not specify a control/comparison group, so include for full-text review to confirm design.

The study used PET imaging with radioligand [11C]NNC 112 rather than fMRI. Although it is a human case-control study and uses an n-back working memory task, it fails the required neuroimaging modality criterion (non-fMRI), so it must be excluded.

Confidence 0.60 below threshold 0.75. Abstract addresses working memory and prefrontal activation in schizophrenia versus major depression, relevant to review. However, it does not explicitly state fMRI was used or whether a healthy control group was included. Insufficient modality/design details in abstract—include for full-text review to confirm fMRI, case-control design, and task-based paradigm.

Human fMRI study with schizophrenia patients (n=38) and healthy controls (n=48) using task-based working memory paradigms (verbal and nonverbal), i.e., case-control design. Abstract clearly reports task-based fMRI working memory investigation, meeting all inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports a task-based working memory fMRI study in childhood-onset schizophrenia. It fits the review objective (fMRI WM in schizophrenia) and involves human participants. The abstract does not explicitly state control group, so full-text review is warranted to confirm case-control design, but information provided is sufficient to include for review.

This article is a meta-analysis pooling 56 fMRI studies rather than a primary fMRI study with human participants; exclusion criteria specify review articles/meta-analyses are excluded. Although it addresses working memory in schizophrenia, it is not an original task-based fMRI case-control/experimental study.

Abstract reports an rTMS trial assessing working memory performance and brain structure (structural changes). It does not mention fMRI neuroimaging or a task-based working memory fMRI paradigm. Therefore it does not meet the fMRI requirement.

Human fMRI study involving schizophrenia patients; abstract/title states analyses during rest and working memory tasks, indicating a task-based working memory paradigm. Likely case-control design assessing cognitive correlates. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI working memory studies in schizophrenia.

Abstract reports an event-related fMRI study in human adolescents with early-onset schizophrenia vs matched controls using a task-based visual working memory paradigm. It is a case-control design and meets all inclusion criteria; no exclusion criteria apply.

Human participants (40 schizophrenia patients, 40 controls); task-based verbal working memory paradigm; fMRI neuroimaging; case-control design with control group reported. Abstract directly investigates WM activation/connectivity in schizophrenia, meeting all inclusion criteria.

The study reports working memory training in (presumably healthy) participants and genetic associations, not a clinical sample of schizophrenia patients. Although it uses fMRI connectivity (rest and task), it does not examine working memory in schizophrenia or a case-control schizophrenia vs control design, so it does not meet the review objective.

Title reports working memory-related brain activity in schizophrenia and describes an experimental medicine study; however the abstract does not explicitly state fMRI or presence of a control/comparison group. Insufficient detail to confirm fMRI and design from abstract alone — include for full-text review.

Abstract explicitly describes the paper as a review of working memory dysfunction in schizophrenia rather than an original fMRI case-control or experimental study. No primary fMRI methods, participants, or task-based results are reported.

Study population is patients with delusional disorder, not schizophrenia. Although it reports task-based fMRI of working memory in humans, it does not address the review’s target population (schizophrenia), so it should be excluded.

The study used structural MRI morphometric analyses (surface-based mapping) rather than task-based fMRI. Although human case-control groups and working memory measures are present, it does not meet the fMRI neuroimaging criterion.

Human study with schizophrenia patients and healthy controls (n=22, n=15); uses fMRI to assess cerebral activations; employs task-based working memory paradigms (verbal and spatial); case-control design. No exclusion criteria met.

Abstract reports behavioral and neural evidence for working memory in schizophrenia but does not specify the neuroimaging modality (fMRI) or clearly state a case-control design or task details. Insufficient information to confirm inclusion criteria; include for full-text review to verify fMRI, task-based WM paradigm, and control group.

Human case-control study comparing schizophrenic patients and healthy controls using event-related fMRI during a spatial working memory task; task-based WM paradigm and fMRI modality clearly reported, meeting all inclusion criteria.

Study reports fMRI during an n-back in healthy subjects (n=137) correlating polygenic risk scores with activation; no schizophrenia patient group or clear case-control comparison is reported. Does not match objective of fMRI working-memory studies in schizophrenia.

Human study using fMRI during an n-back working-memory task; includes a case-control comparison (unmedicated schizophrenia patients and matched healthy controls). Task-based working memory paradigm is used. Although PET was also employed, that does not exclude the study since fMRI data and a control group are reported.

Confidence 0.65 below threshold 0.75. Abstract addresses working memory deficits in schizophrenia but does not explicitly state fMRI, task paradigm, or case-control design. Because it directly concerns working memory in schizophrenia and may be an fMRI study, include for full-text review to determine imaging modality, task-based paradigm, and presence of control group.

Human participants (first-episode schizophrenia patients and healthy controls); fMRI measures including task-evoked activations during an n-back working memory task and resting-state ALFF; case-control design with control group; task-based working memory paradigm. Fits all inclusion criteria.

Human study of patients with schizophrenia using task-based working memory and fMRI activation of DLPFC; includes comparison by medication status (case-control implied). Meets fMRI, human, task-based WM, and comparison-group criteria.

Human study using fMRI with a task-based working memory paradigm; case-control design comparing 41 schizophrenia patients and 42 healthy controls. Meets all inclusion criteria and no exclusion criteria are present.

This paper is a systematic review and coordinate-based meta-analysis of fMRI working memory in healthy adolescents and young adults (not schizophrenia). It is a review/meta-analysis (excluded) and does not study schizophrenia patients or a case-control design with patients, so it does not meet the review objective.

Human fMRI study comparing schizophrenia patients to healthy controls during a task-based visual working memory paradigm; reports activation and functional connectivity measures related to WM performance and symptoms, meeting inclusion criteria.

Human fMRI study using a Sternberg working memory task with 15 schizophrenia patients and 15 healthy controls (case-control, task-based WM paradigm). Meets inclusion criteria (human participants, fMRI, case-control design, task-based WM). No exclusion criteria apparent from abstract.
The study uses functional magnetic resonance spectroscopy (fMRS), not fMRI; this is a non-fMRI imaging modality and therefore meets exclusion criteria.

The study used magnetoencephalography (MEG), a non-fMRI imaging modality, which meets the exclusion criterion for non-fMRI studies. Although it involves human participants, schizophrenia, and a working memory task, the imaging modality disqualifies it.
Human fMRI study using a task-based working memory paradigm in a case-control design (104 schizophrenia patients, 122 healthy controls). Meets all inclusion criteria for the review.
Abstract explicitly states this is a review aiming to reconcile findings; it is not an original task-based fMRI case-control study. Excluded per criterion: review articles/meta-analyses.

Abstract examines dorsolateral prefrontal cortex activity during parametrically manipulated working memory tasks in schizophrenia with healthy comparison subjects (case-control). However, the abstract does not explicitly state fMRI; include for full-text review to confirm imaging modality and details.

Abstract reports a human fMRI study with simultaneous EEG in 18 schizophrenia patients and matched controls performing a working memory task (task-based). Design is case-control and directly addresses working memory in schizophrenia. No exclusion criteria apply.

The study used structural MRI measurements of prefrontal gray matter volumes, not functional MRI. The meta-analysis requires fMRI neuroimaging of working memory; thus it does not meet the fMRI criterion.

Human participants with schizophrenia; 3T fMRI used; randomized double-blind placebo-controlled cross-over (experimental) design; task-based n-back working memory paradigm reported. No exclusion criteria met and abstract provides sufficient information to determine eligibility.

Confidence 0.70 below threshold 0.75. Abstract examines working memory and glutamate in patients with psychosis but does not specify use of fMRI or the presence of a control group. Insufficient information to determine whether this is a task-based fMRI case-control study; include for full-text review to confirm imaging modality and design.

Abstract describes behavioral neuropsychological testing (Wechsler scales, WCST, Trails B) in schizophrenia; no fMRI or other neuroimaging is reported, and no task-based fMRI working memory paradigm. Does not meet fMRI neuroimaging inclusion criterion.

Human participants; task-based spatial working memory paradigm; fMRI neuroimaging; direct comparison between individuals with schizophrenia and healthy controls (case-control design). Abstract clearly meets all inclusion criteria.

Human participants; FMRI data acquired; case-control design with 18 schizophrenia patients and 18 controls; task-based verbal working memory paradigm (novel/practiced stimuli) and WM capacity dual-task. Meets all inclusion criteria.

Human fMRI study using a task-based working memory paradigm (letter N-back) in schizophrenia with healthy comparison participants and experimental randomization to training vs control; meets case-control/experimental design and all inclusion criteria.

Human participants; event-related fMRI; task-based verbal working memory paradigm in schizophrenia. Abstract does not explicitly state a control/comparison group, but study clearly meets review objective and other inclusion criteria. Include for full-text review to confirm presence of case-control design and extract data.
Study uses magnetic resonance spectroscopy (MRS) to measure GABA, not fMRI neuroimaging. Therefore it does not meet the requirement for fMRI task-based working memory studies and should be excluded.

Human fMRI study using an N-back working memory task comparing schizophrenia patients and their unaffected relatives (family case-control design). Meets all inclusion criteria: human participants, fMRI neuroimaging, task-based working memory paradigm, and comparative design.

Study uses functional near-infrared spectroscopy (fNIRS), not fMRI. The review seeks fMRI studies of working memory in schizophrenia; modality mismatch meets exclusion criteria despite human, case-control WM design.

This is a resting-state fMRI study estimating effective connectivity; although it reports correlations with working memory performance, it did not use a task-based working memory fMRI paradigm, so it fails the task-based WM inclusion criterion.

Human schizophrenia patients compared to healthy controls using fMRI in a group comparison (case-control) design. Task explicitly involved facial working memory (neutral face images as mnemonic content). All inclusion criteria met; no exclusion criteria apparent from abstract.

Human fMRI study with 37 schizophrenia patients and 37 matched healthy controls using a task-based working memory change-detection paradigm emphasizing storage. It is a case-control, task-based fMRI study and meets all inclusion criteria.

Human fMRI case-control study with 14 schizophrenia patients and 14 matched controls using a task-based working memory paradigm (modified Sternberg) with fMRI outcomes directly addressing working memory in schizophrenia.

This is a scoping review/theoretical paper summarizing studies of memory in clinical high-risk (prodromal) individuals. It is not an original task-based fMRI case-control study of working memory in schizophrenia; review articles are excluded.

Human early-onset schizophrenia sample studied for DLPFC activation and functional connectivity during working memory, indicating a task-based fMRI case-control study. Meets inclusion criteria (human, fMRI task-based WM, case-control design).

Abstract reports task-based fMRI investigation of working memory networks in schizophrenia using whole-brain, multi-experiment analyses. It targets WM in human schizophrenia patients, fitting the review objective. The abstract does not explicitly state whether a healthy control/comparison group was included, so information is insufficient to confirm all inclusion criteria; include for full-text review to verify design and presence of controls.
Abstract describes a review/theoretical overview of working memory and schizophrenia, not an original task-based fMRI case-control or experimental study. Excluded as a review article per criteria.

Human participants (schizophrenia patients and healthy controls), task-based fMRI during the Sternberg working-memory paradigm, and a case-control design are explicitly reported, meeting all inclusion criteria.

Human fMRI study using a task-based working memory (n-back) paradigm with a control/comparison group (healthy controls vs. first-degree relatives). The study specifically addresses an intermediate phenotype for schizophrenia (DLPFC–hippocampus connectivity) and is relevant to working memory in the context of schizophrenia risk. No exclusion criteria apply; include for full-text review to confirm patient group relevance and extract data.

Human fMRI study with 147 schizophrenia patients and 147 controls examining multimodal (including fMRI) co-alterations linked to working memory performance. Abstract does not explicitly state a task-based working memory paradigm, so inclusion for full-text review is warranted to determine task-based fMRI details.

Abstract describes an fMRI study of working memory in first-episode schizophrenia with human participants and task-based WM processes. The abstract does not explicitly state presence of a control/comparison group, so include for full-text review to confirm case-control design.

Confidence 0.60 below threshold 0.75. Abstract investigates working-memory-related neural substrates in schizophrenia, implying task-based fMRI in human participants and includes comparison between preserved vs poor insight (a comparator). However, the abstract does not explicitly state fMRI or presence of healthy controls; full-text needed to confirm eligibility.

Human fMRI study with case-control design (10 schizophrenia patients vs 10 healthy controls) using a task-based spatial N-back working memory paradigm. Meets all inclusion criteria; no exclusion criteria evident from abstract.

Human fMRI study using a task-based working memory paradigm (Sternberg Item Recognition) with a case-control design (115 schizophrenia patients, 130 healthy controls). Meets all inclusion criteria and no exclusion criteria are apparent from the abstract.

Human participants (patients with schizophrenia and unaffected siblings), task-based working memory paradigm, and assessment of the functional connectome (implying task-fMRI) with comparison groups present. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of working memory in schizophrenia.

Human participants (63 schizophrenia patients, 118 healthy controls); task-based working memory paradigm assessed with fMRI; case-control design with controls; directly addresses working memory in schizophrenia. Meets all inclusion criteria.
The paper is a meta-analysis of 52 studies (a review article), which meets the exclusion criterion 'Review articles, meta-analyses, or theoretical papers'. Not an original fMRI case-control study.

Abstract describes structural gray matter volume measures and behavioral working memory performance in schizotypal personality disorder; no mention of fMRI acquisition or task-based fMRI. Also population is SPD rather than schizophrenia. Excluded for not meeting the fMRI neuroimaging criterion (and not clearly addressing schizophrenia).

Abstract reports an fMRI study in human participants (19 schizophrenia patients, 23 matched controls) using a task-based working memory binding paradigm with a case-control design; no exclusion criteria apply.

This is a resting-state fMRI study (regional homogeneity) in first-episode schizophrenia and does not use a task-based working memory paradigm, so it does not meet the review's task-based working memory inclusion criterion.

The study used EEG (electroencephalograph) data rather than fMRI. The review’s exclusion criteria disallow non-fMRI imaging modalities (e.g., EEG), so it does not meet the imaging-method inclusion criterion.

The study uses resting-state fMRI analyses (degree centrality, Granger causality) relating to facial working memory rather than a task-based working memory paradigm required for inclusion; thus it does not meet the task-based fMRI criterion. Control-group status is also unclear.

Human fMRI study with a case-control design using a task-based working memory paradigm (delayed match-to-sample) comparing schizophrenia patients and matched healthy controls. Abstract clearly meets all inclusion criteria.

fulltext_screening_results.reason: This is a human case-control fMRI study of working memory in schizophrenia. Sample: 40 schizophrenia patients and 58 healthy controls. Neuroimaging: task-based fMRI acquired at 3T with EPI sequences and brainstem-focused analyses. Design: between-group (patients vs. controls) comparisons and subgroup analyses. Task: parametric n-back working memory paradigm (x/1/2/3-back). No exclusion criteria are met (not an animal study, not a review/meta-analysis, uses fMRI, includes a control group). Therefore all inclusion criteria are satisfied.

The study meets all inclusion criteria: human participants (patients with schizophrenia and healthy controls), task-based fMRI neuroimaging (n-back working memory paradigm), and a case–control design (neuroimaging subsample of 70 patients and 70 matched controls; genetic association sample also includes controls). The methods explicitly describe fMRI acquisition, n-back task contrasts (2-back vs baseline, 2-back vs 1-back) and whole-brain analyses of working memory-related activations. No exclusion criteria apply (not an animal study, not a review/meta-analysis, uses fMRI, includes control/comparison group). Therefore it is appropriate to include this study in a meta-analysis of fMRI working memory in schizophrenia.

This study reports original human fMRI research using a task-based working memory paradigm (n-back) in patients with schizophrenia, unaffected siblings, and healthy controls. It uses a case-control design with clearly described participant groups (SZs, SBs, HCs), MRI acquisition and preprocessing, ROI-based analyses, and task-related outcomes. All inclusion criteria are met: human participants, fMRI neuroimaging, task-based working memory paradigm, and comparison groups. No exclusion criteria apply (not an animal study, review, or non-fMRI modality). Therefore it should be included in the review of fMRI studies of working memory in schizophrenia.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: it is a human study (N=202 total: 178 healthy controls, 24 individuals with schizophrenia), uses task-based fMRI (BOLD EPI) during an N-back working memory paradigm, and employs a case-control design comparing schizophrenia patients to matched healthy controls. The methods, participants, and outcomes explicitly report working-memory-related brain activity and between-group comparisons. No exclusion criteria are violated (not an animal study, review, or non-fMRI modality only). Therefore it is eligible for inclusion in the review of fMRI studies of working memory in schizophrenia.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: human participants (first-episode psychosis patients and healthy controls), task-based fMRI (Sternberg Item-Recognition Paradigm) was used to probe working memory (encoding and retrieval), and the design is case-control (patients vs. matched healthy volunteers). Although PET was also used to assess CB1 receptor availability, that does not violate exclusion criteria since fMRI neuroimaging and task-based WM outcomes are primary and clearly reported. The study reports task performance and whole-brain and ROI fMRI results comparing groups, satisfying the review objective of identifying fMRI studies of working memory in schizophrenia.

This is a human fMRI study using a task-based working memory paradigm (Self-Ordered Working Memory Task). It employs a case-control design with 51 patients (21 unmedicated, 30 medicated) and 45 healthy controls, and reports task performance and task-based BOLD fMRI results (ROI and whole-brain analyses). It is not an animal study, review, or non-fMRI modality, and includes a control/comparison group. All inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is a human fMRI study in patients with schizophrenia using a task-based working memory paradigm (N-back; digit span) and real-time fMRI functional connectivity–informed neurofeedback. It employed a two-arm nonrandomized controlled experimental design with a control group, meeting the requirement for a comparison group. fMRI acquisition and task-based analyses (N‑back localizer and NF runs) are central to the methods and outcomes, and cognitive working-memory outcomes are reported. No exclusion criteria (animal study, review, non-fMRI modality, or lack of comparator) apply. Note: the control group did not undergo MRI, but a behavioral control/comparison group was present, and the study still qualifies for inclusion under the review’s criteria focusing on fMRI working-memory studies in schizophrenia.

This is a human experimental study in patients with schizophrenia using task-based fMRI (DOT delayed-response spatial working memory task). Design is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled three-period crossover (within-subject experimental comparison), providing a control/placebo condition. The study reports fMRI outcomes related to working memory (DLPFC activity) and behavioral working memory measures. It is not an animal study, review, or non-fMRI modality, and includes appropriate comparisons, so it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

This is a human, task-based fMRI study of working memory in schizophrenia with a case-control design. Experiment 1 reports event-related fMRI data from schizophrenic outpatients and healthy controls performing a spatial delayed-response working memory task, directly addressing the review objective. It is not an animal study, review, or theoretical paper, and includes a control/comparison group. Although the paper also includes NIRS (Experiment 2), the presence of fMRI data meeting all inclusion criteria qualifies it for inclusion. Note: sample size in the fMRI experiment is small (8 patients, 7 controls), but this does not violate inclusion criteria.

This is a human fMRI study in individuals with schizophrenia using a task-based working memory paradigm (fractal n-back). The design is an experimental, double-blind, placebo-controlled, randomized within-subject crossover comparing drug versus placebo, providing a valid comparison group. BOLD fMRI was acquired and analyzed with task-based contrasts focusing on working-memory-related ROIs (DLPFC, ACC, striatum), and primary outcomes include task fMRI activation. No exclusion criteria are violated (not an animal study, review, or non-fMRI modality). Although there is no healthy control group, the study meets the review’s inclusion criteria of human participants, fMRI neuroimaging, experimental design, and task-based working memory paradigm, so it should be included.

This is an event-related BOLD fMRI study in human participants directly addressing working memory in schizophrenia. It uses a task-based phonological delayed-match-to-sample working memory paradigm, includes a case-control design (12 patients with schizophrenia/schizoaffective disorder vs 13 healthy controls), and reports task-related fMRI activation comparisons. Imaging modality, participant characteristics, and task clearly meet all inclusion criteria, and no exclusion criteria (animal study, review, non-fMRI modality, or lack of control group) apply.

This is a human fMRI study using a task-based working memory paradigm (N-back). It employs a case-control design with schizophrenia patients and matched healthy controls (also includes unaffected parents vs age-matched controls). Imaging modality is fMRI; outcomes are task-elicited BOLD activations during working memory. All inclusion criteria (human participants, fMRI neuroimaging, case-control/experimental design, task-based working memory) are satisfied, and none of the exclusion criteria (animal study, review/meta-analysis, non-fMRI modality, lack of control group) apply. Therefore the study should be included in the meta-analysis of working memory fMRI in schizophrenia.

execution_stats.search_query: schizophrenia AND working memory AND fMRI
